data.text: Contents
Introduction
Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust is committed to ensure a high quality and effective estate maintenance system is in place that ensures:
The continuous provision of functionally suitable facilities for healthcare provision creating a safe pleasant environment internally and externally;
Maintenance of the integrity of the building fabric and building services, public health and utility systems, equipment and site infrastructure which comprises the Facilities;
Minimal disruption to the Trust's operations in the delivery of the Estate Service;

An efficient, responsive, comprehensive and effective Estate Service which is based on sound technical and operational requirements in compliance with codes and policies of good practice and industry and statutory standards;
All plant, equipment, buildings, utility services and site infrastructure do not cause or create any hazard to the environment and / or any person on the Trust site(s); and

A safe environment and safe working practices including the use of recognised risk assessment / management systems to ensure the standards stay high, and that any slippage is recognised and corrected.
Scope
The purpose of this document is to:

This document outlines the framework to ensure the structure, fabric and finishes of Trust premises remain in good repair and fit for purpose - through a planned and reactive maintenance programme delivered by the estates services and related contracts. Hard FM related services include maintenance, pest control and grounds and gardens.

Planned preventative maintenance, reactive maintenance and services for all properties, owned or leased by the Trust will include electrical, mechanical, plumbing, joinery, building, painting, security, fire alarms, flooring etc. A programme of works will be prepared annually to cover the schedule of requirements for each property. A programme of works will be prepared annually to cover the schedule of requirements for each property.

Obligations and standards required for planned preventative maintenance, reactive maintenance and services for the PFI buildings are contained within the PFI Project Agreement. As such, all references within this policy are to hospital premises other than the PFI building and to the obligations, requirements and functions of the Trust's Estates Department unless specifically referenced as otherwise. Specific obligations regarding the timing of issue of programmes of work for the PFI building are contained within the PFI Project Agreement.

data.text: Role and responsibilities within the Trust
EFM Governance Board

EFM Governance Board has responsibility for actively reviewing all EFM policies and procedures and approving substantial changes or new policies and procedures. In addition the EFM Governance Board will be responsible for the monthly review of the EFM Risk Register, annual Management Review of Management Systems in accordance with ISO 9001, ISO 14001 and ISO 45001:2018) and making overall decisions within the EFM directorate Management Team
Health and Safety Management Group (HSMG)

The Health and safety Management Group is responsible for reviewing all aspects of health and safety within the Trust. The Group supports implementation of Health and safety related matters to meet legislative compliance and best practice guidance and actively promotes a continuing positive safety culture throughout all MSE services and sites.
Chief Executive

The Chief Executive of the Trust has overall responsibility for ensuring that all premises are maintained to the relevant standards. The responsibility is delegated to the Chief Estates and Facilities Officer to implement.
Senior Estates and Facilities Director

The Senior Estates and Facilities Director is accountable for the leadership and strategic management of the Estates and Facilities directorate and is committed to the establishment, implementation and maintenance of the integrated management system, defining the role and responsibilities and working relationship for all Estates and Facilities personnel and acting as the Principle Engineer.
Director of Specialist Services

The Director of Specialist Services is responsible for the smooth delivery of specialist services which include sustainability, health safety, fire safety, compliance and specialist operations services including Medical Equipment and Sterile Services. This role is committed to the compliance against all relevant statutory, mandatory and national standards for health and safety for all Trust owned properties and assets.
Director of Estates and Facilities Operations

The Director of Estates and Facilities Operations is the responsible for the management and delivery of the operational services within the EFM directorate and is committed to the maintenance of the integrated management system and defines the role and responsibilities and working relationship for all Estates and Facilities personnel within the operational teams.
EFM Site Managers

The EFM Site Managers provides a strategic direction for the site based services which are filtered down from the overall EFM strategy and business improvement plans - ensuring that each service provides excellent quality services to patients with a cost effective approach.
Managing the service contractors and ensuring they adhere to contractual agreement and the delivery of excellent service.

The EFM Site Managers are the operational, strategic and financial lead for all the hard and soft services including maintenance, grounds and gardens, catering, domestics, linen, portering, staff accommodation and waste management.
The EFM Site Managers have overall responsibility for its development and day-to- day hard and soft services management.
Maintenance Managers

Maintenance Managers are responsible for the day to day running of their services including the delivery and working in accordance with operational processes, training of staff, HR requirements and ensure related policies and procedures are in place and reflective of current situation and suitable for use.
Capital Projects Team

The Capital Projects Manager under the direction of the Senior Director of Estates and Facilities is responsible for the overall programme management of all Estate and Facilities is responsible for the overall programme management of all state Capital Development Schemes. The Capital Projects Team shall ensure all new works are efficient in terms of value for money (VFM), energy usage, reducing future maintenance requirements and to comply with relevant HTM/HBN's and other legation.

The Capital Projects Manager under the direction of the Senior Director of Estates and Facilities will also monitor progress of agreed schemes and prepare and issue reports to inform and advise Trust Senior Management on a regular basis, all in accordance with Trust Policies and Procedures.
All Estates/Maintenence trades' staff

All staff are required to adhere to all EFM policies and procedures. Estates trade staff are employed to work across both building and engineering disciplines (mechanical and electrical). Their level of responsibility includes (but is not limited to) fabric maintenance, steam boilers and CHP plant, lifts, compressors, fire systems, emergency generators, electrical, heating, cooling and water systems, drains and security access systems.
Grounds and Gardens
The Estates Grounds and Gardens Team comprise groundsman and gardeners and will undertake a range of duties to support the upkeep of grounds and gardens under direction from Supervisors.
All staff
All staff have a responsibility to report any faults and hazards in accordance with the Trust's Health and safety and Risk Management policies.
Hard FM operational systems
Standards

All maintenance, servicing and inspection works are to be carried out in accordance with the relevant British Standards, HTM Guidance, Building Regulations, Codes of Practice, Health and Safety at Work Act, Regulatory Reform (Fire Safety) Order 2005, CDM Regulations and manufacturers' instructions. Standards or service and working practice is monitored and reported in accordance with the EFM Evaluation and Assurance Policy.
Reactive maintenance

Reactive maintenance is a repair service request normally by the user department. When faults are reported they are allocated a priority from urgent to routine depending upon the nature of the fault. The priority will generally attract a pre-set response time.

All Trust staff (or any patient or visitor) can report any failure or want of repair or other matter which they believe to require Reactive Maintenance at any time via the site Estates Helpdesk or via the email reporting process. Failure or wants of repair reported to the Estates Helpdesk will be classified as emergency, urgent or routine and responded to by the relevant department. Each request is allocated a priority and unique identification with response times and priorities defined by the relevant service or in accordance with the PFI Project Agreements where the request relates to a PFI maintained building.
Planned Preventative Maintenance (PPM)

Planned Preventative Maintenance (PPM) is the routine inspection and/or servicing of equipment, or the planned repair or replacement of components, elements or systems. On time or hours run basis (e.g. lubrication, fire alarm testing, filter changes etc.).

The EFM directorate shall establish and maintain suitable systems and procedures to ensure that Planned Preventative Maintenance is carried out at such times and in such manner that all the required standards detailed by the Department of Health and/or as recommended by manufacturers are met in relation to the site, the premises, plant and equipment, and in such a manner as to minimise disruption to the provision of high quality healthcare.

If as a result of unforeseen events critical Planned Maintenance takes longer than planned or is required to be brought forward, the Maintenance Department acknowledges that certain non-critical maintenance may need to be re-scheduled to accommodate this. In such an event, the Maintenance Department shall ensure that the re-scheduled non-critical maintenance is carried out as soon as reasonably practicable.
Irregular maintenance work
Irregular maintenance or cyclical maintenance work is carried out in accordance with planned recurrent often multi-year cycles (e.g. redecoration, flooring renewals).
Backlog maintenance

Backlog maintenance is a term which covers situations where there is long standing outstanding maintenance which can only be tackled by larger investment projects. These types of maintenance issues are identified through risk assessments, service reports, backlog surveys and are incorporated into the Trust Capital Programme where funding allows.
Minor works

Minor works (also known small works) is the term which covers small items of Estates works involving adaptation, alteration and new installations which are often required to support changes in procedures and work practices. The typical value of Minor Works is below £5,000.

Where alterations or improvements are required these require to be specifically funded, normally from an appropriate revenue budget. For this type of work a Small Works Request Form (available on Intranet) will be completed by the requesting directorate/department and should be submitted to the relevant site estates team. On receipt the works will be quoted and will not proceed until approved by the budget holder and designated senior lead for the directorate.
Capital expenditure

Capital expenditure is defined as expenditure on a tangible productive resource with an expected life in excess of one year. The items will usually require repair and maintenance. The capitalisation threshold has been determined as expenditure of £5,000 (including VAT where this is not recoverable). All works and queries regarding capital works need to be approved prior to progression.
Service contracts

Maintenance carried out by an external contractor at permitted intervals and intended to reduce the probability of failure, breakdown or the performance degradation of an asset. All servicing of plant, equipment and installations is to be carried out at the prescribed intervals.

Any deviance from manufacturers' recommendations or HTM guidance must be subject to a risk assessment. All parties are to ensure that competent persons are employed to carry out the specific services, and are to maintain a register of competent persons. Records of servicing will be maintained together with appropriate certificates.
Out of hour emergency maintenance service

This service provides a 365 day maintenance service that operates outside of normal working hours. It is accessed through the hospital switchboard. The objective of the Out of Hour's Service is to make safe plant or equipment and to repair or rectify critical items or maintain safe service. Calls are logged by the switch board and the on Call Estates Operations Manager/Officer is contacted to assist ad they will determine the course of action.
Rechargeable repairs
These are repairs required following wilful damage to the Trust structure, fixtures and fittings.
Estates helpdesk
The estates helpdesk is the middle service between the customers and the Maintenance department. Services within this department include:
Processing jobs that are reported through email, phone call and on the portal.
Access area for contractors to sign in and out and collect ID badges (in accordance with the Control of Contractor Policy).
Notification of problems
All parties are to notify the user department immediately of any significant building and engineering breakdowns which will have an immediate impact on the delivery of a service from a building.

The Trust's estates department will ensure that all affected Heads of Service are informed and given advice on the effects on the service provided from the building. This is expected to be undertaken by the individual user departments using the Trust “Risk Assessment Form” in accordance with the Risk Management Strategy and Policy.

For all planned works that will result in a loss of service or interference to the users must have 2 weeks' notice in advance to the users, an Essential Works Notification will be issued Trust wide to ensure all parties possibly affected will be informed. A sign off sheet for acceptance may be used for specific work.
Hard FM speciality subjects
Within the Estates remit are a number of speciality subjects including:
Asbestos
Confined spaces
Electrical safety – high and low voltage
Grounds and gardens
Lead at work
Lifting equipment
Lifts
Medical gas/ non-medical gas
Pest control
Pneumatic air
Pressure systems
Water safety
Window safety

While the Chief Executive and the Board of Directors carry ultimate responsibility for the safe and secure healthcare environment, the structure below represents the professional adopted approach to the delivery of high risk impact specialist services within the Trust as listed above in section 6.1. These roles are detailed in relevant estates policies for these specialist subjects and a register maintained by the EFM Compliance Team to ensure suitable appointments are maintained

6.2.1 Designated Person (DP)

This person provides the essential senior management link between the organisation and professional support, which also provides independence of the audit-reporting process. The DP will also provide an informed position at board level
6.2.2 Authorising Engineer (AE)

The AE will act as an independent professional adviser to the healthcare organisation. The AE should be appointed by the organisation with a brief to provide services in accordance with the relevant HTM. The professional status and role required may vary in accordance with the specialist service being supported.

The AE will act as assessor and make recommendations for the appointment of Authorised Persons (APs), monitor the performance of the service, and provide an annual audit to the DP. The AE, to effectively carry out this role, particularly with regard to audit, should remain independent of the operational structure of the healthcare organisation.
6.2.3 Authorised Person (AP)

The AP has the key operational responsibility for the specialist service. This person will be qualified and sufficiently experienced and skilled to fully operate the specialist service. They will be nominated by the AE, appointed by the healthcare organisation and be able to demonstrate:
Their understanding through familiarisation with the system and attendance at an appropriate professional course;
Competency;
A level of experience; and
Evidence of knowledge and skills
An important element of this role is the maintenance of records, quality of service and maintenance of system safety (integrity).
The AP will also be responsible for establishing and maintaining the validation of Competent Persons (CPs), who may be employees of the organisation or appointed contractors.
Larger sites will need more than one AP for a particular service.
6.2.4 Competent Person (CP)

This person provides skilled installation and/or maintenance of the specialist service. The CP will be appointed, or authorised to work (if a contractor), by the AP. They will demonstrate a sound trade background and specific skill in the specialist service. They will work under the direction of the AP and in accordance with operating procedures, policies and standards of the service.
Training requirements

All Estates staff must be trained to the standard for the relevant task undertaken. The operatives are to be competent persons in their discipline. Regular reviews of training requirements are to be undertaken and refresher training is to be implemented as necessary within any financial constraints imposed. The Estates and Facilities Site Manager is to ensure adequate funding is available to fulfil all statutory training requirements for all operatives.
The PFI providers training obligations are covered by the Schedules within their Contracts.

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the (EFM Governance Board, which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local policy and procedure guidelines. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the EFM Governance Board of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
